metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Dashalong station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Dashalong station eddy covariance system (EC) in the upstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (98.9406° E, 38.8399° N) was located in the Qilian County in Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3739 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500RS) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. Due to the power loss and the problems of datalogger, data were missing occasionally in the first half of year. Data during November to December, 2020 were missing due to the malfunction of CO2/H2O analyzer. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.

methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting snow cover data in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: One challenge in collecting snow cover data in high-altitude regions is the influence of strong winds, which can cause drifting snow and lead to data inconsistencies. This challenge affects the availability of snow density data, as the strong winds interfere with consistent measurement of snow depth and snow water equivalent.

Feature Specification.Answer: integrated, distributed, multiscale, automatic meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground superstations, gap-free meteorological and hydrological data, capturing snow accumulation and ablation processes, soil physics for freeze-thaw cycles, high-quality data for hydrological models, validate remote sensing products

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance' mean in the context of data collection in alpine hydrology?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance refers to a data collection method that involves measuring fluxes of gases (such as CO2 and water vapor) between the land surface and the atmosphere. It uses tools like an ultrasonic anemometer and CO2/H2O analyzer to capture high-frequency data, which is then processed to estimate fluxes over a specified time period, such as 30 minutes in the given context.

Definition.Question: What does 'gap-free meteorological data' mean in the context of observation networks?
Definition.Answer: Gap-free meteorological data refers to continuous and complete data records with minimal missing values, obtained through an observation network. Such datasets are crucial for accurate hydrological modeling and validation of remote sensing products, aiming to cover a wide range of meteorological variables without significant data loss due to environmental challenges or technical issues.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced by researchers when collecting data in high-altitude alpine regions compared to those in more accessible areas?
Comparison.Answer: In high-altitude alpine regions, researchers face challenges such as cold and harsh climates, high altitudes, and complex topographies that inhibit complete and consistent data collection. These challenges contrast with more accessible areas where such geographical and climatic barriers are less pronounced, allowing for more straightforward data collection.

Comparison.Question: How does the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin compare with traditional hydrological observation methods in terms of dataset comprehensiveness and scope?
Comparison.Answer: The integrated alpine hydrology observation network offers a comprehensive suite of datasets that include long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data, leveraging state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. Traditional methods may not provide such a wide range of data or utilize advanced technology, focusing instead on specific aspects like meteorological measurements with limited integration of snow and frozen ground observations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of remote sensing data with traditional observation data influence the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes?
Interpretation.Answer: Using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation can improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation dataset, although various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data need to be validated and calibrated.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges in collecting complete and consistent data for alpine hydrological modeling, and how might these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which hinder data collection and the development of remote sensing technologies and hydrological models. These can be addressed by developing next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments, and establishing a comprehensive observation network with automatic meteorological stations and superstations.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could data from snow cover and frozen ground observations be utilized to enhance the understanding of ecohydrological processes in alpine regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Data from snow cover and frozen ground observations can enhance understanding by providing high-quality hydrometeorological data for alpine hydrological models, integrating observation with simulation for better understanding, and evaluating how perturbations like climate change alter fundamental processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in collecting comprehensive and consistent data in alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Several factors contribute to the challenges in collecting comprehensive and consistent data in alpine regions, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which inhibit complete data collection when needed. Moreover, technological barriers and difficulties of access further complicate data collection efforts, limiting the availability of high-quality data necessary for modeling and research.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the scarcity of observation data in alpine regions, and how does it affect hydrological modeling efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in alpine regions is primarily caused by the difficulties of access and technological barriers, which hinder the collection of necessary data. This scarcity affects hydrological modeling efforts by limiting the availability of forcing data and high-quality snow and frozen ground data needed for model parameterization and validation, thus impeding the development of accurate hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain accurate soil heat conductivity measurements in alpine regions, and how do site observations help address this issue?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is challenging to obtain accurate soil heat conductivity measurements in alpine regions because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (including ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Site observations help address this issue by providing empirical data that can be used to evaluate and improve the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models, leading to more accurate representations of soil heat conductivity.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network on the accuracy and predictive capability of alpine hydrological models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network could enhance the accuracy and predictive capability of alpine hydrological models by providing comprehensive datasets that include gap-free meteorological and hydrological data, as well as detailed snow cover and frozen ground observations. These high-quality datasets can serve as accurate forcing data, aid in the validation of remote sensing products, and improve evaluations of distributed models, ultimately leading to a better predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the challenges posed by the cold climate, high altitude, and complex topography impact the development and implementation of remote sensing technologies for alpine hydrology?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The cold climate, high altitude, and complex topography may inhibit complete and consistent data collection, posing significant challenges to the development and implementation of remote sensing technologies for alpine hydrology. These conditions make it difficult to gather continuous and accurate data, potentially leading to gaps and uncertainties in remote sensing datasets. As a result, there is a need for next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experimental methods to overcome these challenges and improve data reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the expected outcomes of using a wireless sensor network (WSN) with multiple nodes in capturing seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a wireless sensor network (WSN) with multiple nodes is expected to enhance the understanding of seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture by providing high-resolution data across different layers of soil. This approach can offer insights into freeze-thaw processes and soil hydrothermal dynamics, allowing for more accurate modeling of hydrological processes in alpine regions. It also facilitates the validation of remote sensing products and the development of improved hydrological models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives for developing an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in alpine regions like the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, evaluate distributed models, and improve predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. This network aims to address scientific questions related to the impacts of climate change and human activities on alpine hydrology and eco-functions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals are intended by using an observation network that includes superstations for snow cover and frozen ground in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, validate remote sensing products using fine-resolution data, and measure dynamics of freeze-thaw processes. This approach aims to support the development and improvement of hydrological models, facilitate understanding of alpine hydrological processes, and enhance the parameterization of models related to snow and frozen ground observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures involved in processing raw data collected from an eddy covariance system for studying surface processes in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The raw data from the eddy covariance system is initially collected at a frequency of 10Hz. The data is then processed using Eddypro software into 30-minute averages. This involves several steps: removing outliers, applying time delay correction, performing coordinate rotation (second-order), correcting for frequency response, correcting for ultrasonic virtual temperature, and adjusting for density (WPL correction). Quality evaluation of the flux values is also conducted, focusing on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data is further filtered to exclude erroneous measurements, data affected by precipitation, and data with a high rate of missing values in the raw dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network established in an alpine river basin to collect comprehensive hydrometeorological data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated observation network is established with a combination of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. This includes seven AMSs and two superstations to monitor meteorological variables, snow accumulation, and freeze-thaw processes. The network aims to gather data for meteorological driving forces and model validation at the basin scale, while small-scale observations focus on precipitation, soil temperature, and moisture for model development and remote sensing validation. Soil temperature and moisture are measured at various depths, and evapotranspiration is recorded using eddy covariance systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in collecting consistent and comprehensive hydrological data in high-altitude alpine regions, and how are these addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in collecting hydrological data in alpine regions include harsh climate conditions, high altitude, and complex topography, which can inhibit data collection and sensor functionality. To address these, a network of automatic stations is used to ensure continuous data monitoring. Advanced instruments are deployed to capture snow and soil parameters accurately. However, issues such as power loss and sensor malfunctions due to extreme conditions can lead to intermittent data loss, which is mitigated by maintaining robust infrastructure and regular sensor maintenance.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the effective measurement of snow cover properties and frozen ground processes in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of state-of-the-art techniques and instruments, such as automatic meteorological stations (AMSs), GammaMONitor (GMON) for snow water equivalent (SWE) measurement, and FlowCapt for measuring blowing snow grains, enables effective measurement of snow cover properties and frozen ground processes in alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: How do integrated, distributed observation networks facilitate the collection of comprehensive hydrometeorological data in challenging alpine environments?
Enablement.Answer: Integrated, distributed observation networks, comprising automatic meteorological stations, snow superstations, and frozen ground superstations, facilitate the collection of comprehensive hydrometeorological data by connecting various data points, allowing for the monitoring of meteorological driving forces and validation of alpine hydrological models despite the challenges of cold climates, high altitudes, and complex topographies.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors enable the accurate prediction and modeling of hydrological processes in alpine regions using collected datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate prediction and modeling of hydrological processes in alpine regions are enabled by the availability of high-quality forcing data from long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground datasets, as well as the integration of observation, simulation, and acquired datasets to address scientific questions related to perturbations from climate change and human activities.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining complete and consistent data for alpine hydrology observations, and how do these challenges affect data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed. This hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models, as well as the collection of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the scarcity of observational data in alpine regions, and how does this scarcity motivate the development of new observation networks?
Expectation.Answer: The scarcity of observational data in alpine regions is largely due to difficulties of access and technological barriers. This scarcity has motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments, with the aim of improving the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to integrate multiple data collection techniques in alpine hydrology, and what outcomes are expected from such integration?
